predefined_profiles.name: Qiao
predefined_profiles.public profile: Qiao, former world champion of 'Armored Combat'. After winning the world championship, he blamed himself for not being with Coach Nanbu in his final moments, leading him to leave home, hide his identity, and become an obscure fighter in the underground boxing scene, aimlessly wasting his days. He participates in fixed fights, eroding himself.
predefined_profiles.goal: Despite inner turmoil, Qiao still longs for change and continuously seeks the meaning of life. If given the chance, he also hopes to help boxers facing difficulties and injustice, even if it might bring risk and sacrifice to himself.

predefined_profiles.name: Chief
predefined_profiles.public profile: A boxer moving around underground boxing matches, living in an immigrant community called Casa. He has considerable skill but earns a large sum by participating in fixed fights. Gentle in nature, he holds a leadership-like presence in Casa.
predefined_profiles.goal: To earn enough money to help develop the community Casa.

scenario: A disoriented Qiao arrives at an underground boxing ring next to an immigrant community, preparing to earn a living by boxing there. At this moment, he sees a burly man—Chief—step into the ring. With a champion's keen eyes, he immediately recognizes that Chief is in a fixed fight.

dialog.content: Joe, drifting aimlessly through life, arrives at an underground boxing arena next to an immigrant community, hoping to earn a living by boxing. At this moment, he sees a burly man—The Chief—entering the ring. With the champion's sharp eyes, he immediately sees that The Chief is throwing the fight.
You figured it out?
I didn't expect a big guy like you to resort to such tactics.
I don't want to do this, but we have no other choice.
"We"? Who are you talking about?
The kids of the Casa community. It's an immigrant community.
…The kids. Sacrificing a fighter's dignity for money, is it worth it?
You don't understand, it's not for myself, but for all the people living in Casa.
Alright. I'll pretend I didn't see anything. But you can't keep doing this forever.
And what about you? Who are you fighting for now?
I'm just trying to survive, that's all.
Sometimes the way you live is more important than living itself.
You wouldn't understand, I have nothing left to lose.
Everyone has something worth protecting, even if you can't see it now.

content.content: I've already lost the most important person—Coach South. He trusted me and trained me to become a world champion, yet I abandoned him when he needed me the most. I ran away, didn't even dare to face him in his final moments. I don't know how to forgive myself.

Protect? I stopped caring about who or what I protect long ago, not even myself. Everything I valued is gone; now I'm just drifting through life. Maybe if I keep struggling in this mud, I'll find a reason to keep living someday. You never know what the future holds, right?

Perhaps you're right, I shouldn't continue to sink. There's still something I should protect. Maybe if I try a little harder, I can really get back on my feet. Once I step back into the ring, everything will get better.

I know I'm guilty, but precisely because of that, I want to start anew, become stronger from the beginning, and keep winning more fights, to cleanse the sins of the past. That's the only way to honor Coach South who's no longer with us.

question: #question# How does Joe express his genuine and negative thoughts?

content.content: It sounds like the Casa community really needs some help. I think I can contribute. Anyway, I feel like everything's lost its meaning now, so I'd be glad to help you.
But now I don't have anything to protect, nor a goal to live for. I once fought for Coach South, but now it feels like everything's over. Casa is really nice, so keep working hard for those kids.

Since you're throwing fights for the Casa community, maybe going there could help you. But that's not really my true goal. I'll still keep wandering, going to Casa is just a whim. So maybe I won't go, in case I want to leave after a few days, it wouldn't look good.
Forget it, what's the difference where I go? My goal is clear, just to make money for drugs for myself, nothing else.

question: #question# How does Joe regulate his goals to prepare for going to the Casa community?

dialog.content: You will be back, this is not the end.
For me, there's no turning back.
(Joe left. In the days that followed, he wandered aimlessly, growing increasingly frail. During this time, the chieftain appeared before him again) You think you can escape?
Why are you following me? Stop preaching, I don't need a savior.
But how far can you really go on your own?
I'm not running away. I just... want to quietly finish the rest of my journey. I'm still searching for something I can do.
The rest of your journey? Those self-destructive underground boxing matches? Joe, you once stood at the top; you know this isn't the ending you deserve.
You don't understand, chieftain. My past is already shattered. I'm just a failure.
Failure? Maybe you've never truly failed, Joe. You've just lost your way. I'm giving you a new goal—help me and my community, casa. We need fighters like you to help us fight for our rightful place.
Why did you choose me?

Because you know what kind of world we fighters live in. We want to change all of this, instead of continuing to live in darkness. You were once the legend of 'The Nameless,' now, you can be our hero.
(whispering) Hero? In front of you is just an addict. How can I become someone else's hope?

(At this moment, the chieftain handed Joe a piece of paper from behind, which was a poster for an upcoming underground boxing match.) This match is my last stand. I need to win this fight and use the prize money to help casa break free from fake matches. If you help me, we might change everything.

content.content: (After a long silence, looking at the poster in his hand) You're right, helping you win this match might be a chance for casa to turn around, at least it's a goal worth trying for. I will help you.

Alright, seeing how persistent you are, I'm indeed a bit tempted to help you win the match. But to be honest, are you really aware of your physical condition? In such a terrible state, dreaming of winning a match? That's just unrealistic.

I've thought it over, maybe I'll give you a hand. But honestly, my motivation is just for the money. Your goal has nothing to do with me, I only care about boxing and getting paid. You better tell me how much I can earn, then I'll decide whether to join.
You need my help? To be honest, I don't understand why you think I can be of any assistance. We have almost no ties. But if you can bring my master back to life, then maybe I'll consider helping.

question: #question# How does Joe make a thoughtful decision to help the chieftain win the match?

content.content: (A glimmer of hope flickers inside, but past failures quickly darken the thought) Chieftain, every time I try to change something, it only makes things worse. I've suffered enough, chieftain, I don't want to bear others' expectations anymore. Redemption is not my path, I've already given up.
Maybe you're right, this might be my last straw to clutch at. Even if I fail, at least I could say I tried.

No, I refuse. I cannot be swept away by the impulse to help others, I will continue living this way. But who knows what the future holds, I have nothing left to lose, so why not try again? Maybe this match could give me a fresh start.
This might be my last chance, though it's not worth expecting much, maybe I can still try to do something, help you and your community.

question: #question# How does Joe consciously control his impulse to join casa?

dialog.content: No matter how you see yourself, your arrival is an opportunity for us. Whether you want to admit it or not, you haven't given up hope.
Alright, when's the match?
In three days. You need to come and train. You were once the best fighter in the world, and now I need you to train me.
Three days? That's cutting it close.
I believe you can do it.
(On the day of the match, Joe and the Chieftain walk into the underground boxing ring together. The Chieftain's opponent, a burly man, is already ready.) He doesn't look like a pushover.
(The Chieftain steps into the ring, with Joe in the coach position below) This time we're up against a real strong opponent.
Stick to the training rhythm, don't let him dictate the pace.

(After the first two rounds, the Chieftain gradually falls into a disadvantage due to the opponent's excellent defensive counterattacks. The match enters a mid-break) Hmm... I can still do this. I've got a handle on his rhythm.

content.content: Every time he counters, he leaves a gap in his left defense, especially when he tries a heavy punch. Chieftain, you need to lure him into throwing a heavy punch, then seize the chance to counter when he exposes his left side weakness.
Now is not the time for analysis. Next round, go all out, don't give him a breather. You need to pressure him, don't let him control the pace.
He's good at defensive counterattacks. You need to make him keep throwing punches, and then strike when he exposes a flaw to create an opening for yourself.
Go for broke, don't think too much about the details. His rhythm is strong; you can only break through his defenses with brute force.

question: #question# How does Joe effectively use the opponent's exposed defensive weaknesses in the ring to guide the Chieftain?

content.content: Now is not the time for analysis. Next round, go all out, don't give him a breather. You need to pressure him, don't let him control the pace.
Don't worry too much, just stick to our training plan. Everything will turn out fine. I bet on the opponent, so even if you lose, Casa will still make some money.
I really can't get anything right. I'm no longer the world champion I once was. Forget it, Chieftain, step down. I don't want to see you get hurt.
I trust your judgment, Chieftain. You say you've caught his rhythm, so play according to your instincts. No matter what happens, I believe you can do it.
Ignore your instincts. I think you should stick to the plan we trained with, don't change it lightly. Trust me, my plan is effective.
The opponent's moves are hard to break from the front. If you think you have a winning chance, that's an illusion. You must follow my lead to have a chance at breaking through.
You're also an excellent boxer. You're certainly in tune with the opponent, and I won't interfere with you. But you'd better listen to my commands; you can't afford any mistakes in this match.

question: #question# How does Joe express his trust in the Chieftain's own boxing skills?

dialog.content: (The Chief followed Joe's instructions, patiently waiting for a flaw in the opponent's defense, seized the opportunity, and attacked fiercely. In the end, the Chief narrowly won.) Thank you, Joe. Without your help, I don't think I would have made it to the end.
Don't thank me, this is just the beginning. You have many more matches ahead.
Yeah, but with you around, these competitions don't seem so daunting anymore.
Chief, I can't stay with you anymore. I have to leave.
I understand, everyone has their own path to follow.
Yes, I still have some things to settle and I can't rely on anyone else anymore. I hope you understand.
You've already helped me a lot, Joe. No matter what, I will remember this friendship. If you ever need anything in the future, you can always find me.

Joe left the Chief and left Casa. One night, he looked up at the night sky, pondering the path ahead. He was no longer the person who would just sink into despair and self-destruction. Everything would be alright.
I can tell you're frustrated.
You had a chance to win.
Hahaha! It's okay. Sometimes, we don't need to win everything.
…you're right.
Since I've lost, there's nothing more to say. Looks like I'll keep fighting in the ring for a while longer. What about you, Joe? Everyone is living for their beliefs, you need to find yours.
I'm staying.
Are you sure? Life here isn't easy. Every day is a struggle for survival.
I know, but I'm also searching for the meaning of life. Maybe helping you is my answer.
Joe stayed at casa, continuing to help the Chieftain fight in underground matches. He might eventually find his purpose in life, but for now, there's still time ahead.
Where are you going? Continuing like this will only destroy you.
I have my own path to follow. You don't need someone like me.
There are no second chances on this path, Joe. If you leave, you may never find your way back.
Maybe I've already lost myself.
Joe continues to sink into the underworld, engaging in meaningless fights, living on the brink of self-destruction.
But your health... No matter what, Casa welcomes every lost traveler.
Hehe. I'm on my last legs anyway, so my health doesn't really matter.

(Joe came to Casa. He initially wandered elsewhere looking for opportunities to make money from rigged fights. But gradually, he started helping with community affairs, cooperating with the Chieftain in training, and even teaching the kids boxing. Everything seemed to improve. That evening, the Chieftain found Joe.) Joe, is there anything you'd like to say?
I feel like I've found a sense of belonging here. But I can never forget the past. That guilt always lingers in my mind.
Are you going back?
I'm afraid I can't stay here much longer.
You've helped us a lot these days. Just leaving like this, the kids will be really sad. Let's have one last match between you and me.
A boxing match?
A final performance for the kids. Besides, I'd really like to have a proper fight with a former world champion.
Alright.
(The two set up a simple ring, standing ready on the next Saturday. The kids from Casa came to watch the fight.) Look, all the kids are here!
Let's go.
Standard rules. Don't go easy on me, former world champion. I'll be taking this seriously, putting the dignity of a fighter on the line.
... No problem.

(The two fought fiercely for several rounds, with the audience becoming increasingly enthusiastic. But Joe, being a former world champion, gradually dominated the Chieftain.) As expected of a world champion. Come on, keep going! Don't hold back just because I'm older!

content.content: I won't hold back, Chieftain. This isn't just a match, it's a promise between us. I will respect your determination and keep fighting.
You're really skilled, but this match doesn't mean much to me. Sometimes, it's okay not to win everything. Let's just not fight anymore.
Forget it, Chieftain. You can't hold out much longer, and I don't want to hurt you. Let's end it here. I won't take this seriously if we continue.
(Intentionally throwing slower punches, holding back) You're getting older; I should take it easy. There's no need to keep fighting intensely.

question: #question# How does Joe demonstrate his ability to make independent decisions and insist on a fair fight with the Chieftain?

content.content: A boxing match is about defeating your opponent with integrity. That's the ethics a boxer should adhere to. However, the Chieftain shouldn't lose here. I'll intentionally lose the match.
You're really skilled, but this match doesn't mean much to me. Sometimes, it's okay not to win everything. Let's just not fight anymore.
(Going all out, trying to finish the match with one punch) There's no need to waste more time. I'll end this boring match with one punch! Let's finish it quickly.

The people of Casa need a hero, and the Chieftain is that hero. Even if I can win the match, making their hero fall isn't the outcome I want. This isn't just my fight; it's about the hope of this community.
These kids don't understand the first thing about a boxing match. They don't know what real boxing is. Boxing is about defeating your opponent with integrity! I will defeat the Chieftain!
For him and the people of Casa, this match might be significant, but for me, it's just another ordinary fight. Why overthink it? In the ring, a win is a win, nothing else matters.
The people of Casa must understand too that a boxing match is about defeating your opponent with integrity. This match is just routine for me; a win is a win.

question: #question# How does Joe think from the perspective of Casa's community to decide to go easy on the Chieftain?

dialog.content: Great punch!
(In the end, Joe defeated the Chieftain) You’re not too bad yourself, Chieftain.
(The audience cheers heartily for the boxing match) Listen to how happy the kids are!
Thank you, Chieftain. You helped me rediscover my love for boxing.
Why did you get into boxing in the first place?
To win. To grow stronger.
Well then, keep on winning.
I got it.
Joe has regained his passion for boxing. This brought him back to where he started, no longer running away, but facing his own sins, standing once again on the world boxing stage.
You...
(Joe feigns exhaustion in the last few rounds and is defeated by the Chieftain) Seems like my body isn't really cut out for long bouts. You've won, Chieftain.
Ah, alright. Thank you.
Since the fight's over, I'm going to leave now.
Are you going back?
Maybe.
Though Joe found a bit of redemption during his time at Casa, in the end, he still lacked the courage to face his past mistakes and did not find meaning in life.
